newsitem.title: VIETNAM: Vietnam urged to release Buddhist church leaders.
newsitem.headline: Vietnam urged to release Buddhist church leaders.

text.p: Buddhists from 20 countries have called on Vietnam to release dozens of detained leaders of the outlawed Unified Buddhist Church of Vietnam (UBCV), a Paris-based group representing the movement said on Tuesday.

The International Buddhist Information Bureau said in a statement that a letter demanding the immediate and unconditional release of Buddhist monks, nuns and others was sent to Hanoi after an international conference in Kanchanaburi, Thailand.

The letter called for the restoration of the UBCV's freedom of religious activity, a halt to a campaign aimed at disbanding the Buddhist Youth Movement and the restoration of all property confiscated by the authorities from the UBCV.

"In Vietnam today, the traditional Unified Buddhist Buddhist Church of Vietnam...is banned, its pagodas are confiscated and its network of educational, social and cultural institutions are closed down," the letter said.
"Monks, nuns and lay-Buddhists have suffered torture, detention and intimidation, and today virtually all of the UBCV leadership is in prison or under house arrest."
An official at the Paris-based group said there were currently 70 UBCV members detained in Vietnam."
The letter was signed by 50 monks, nuns and lay-Buddhists from Asia, the United States and Europe at the conference of the International Network of Engaged Buddhists (INEB).
The UBCV was the Buddhist church organisation in former South Vietnam until the victory of Hanoi's communist forces over the South in 1975.

The UBCV is still regarded by Buddhists in the south and abroad as the sole legitimate church organisation. But the government views the state-sponsored Vietnam Buddhist Church (VBC) as the only legal organisation for Buddhists in Vietnam.
